title: 112_hr1705
content: The Act is titled "Transparency in Regulatory Analysis of Impacts on the Nation Act of 2011." It establishes a committee to analyze regulations affecting energy and manufacturing in the United States. The "Transparency in Regulatory Analysis of Impacts on the Nation Act of 2011" establishes the Committee for the Cumulative Analysis of Regulations that Impact Energy and Manufacturing in the United States. The Committee is composed of officials from various government departments to analyze and report on the impacts of EPA rules and actions. The Committee for the Cumulative Analysis of Regulations that Impact Energy and Manufacturing in the United States is composed of officials from various government departments, including the Energy Information Administration, Department of the Treasury, Environmental Protection Agency, Council of Economic Advisors, Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, Office of Information and Regulatory Affairs, Small Business Administration, and United States International Trade Commission. The Secretary of Commerce serves as the Chair of the Committee. The Committee, chaired by the Secretary of Commerce, consults with members and the Electric Reliability Organization. It terminates 90 days after submitting its final report. SEC. 3. ANALYSES. The Committee will conduct analyses for the years 2016, 2020, and 2030 on the cumulative and incremental impacts of covered rules and actions. Estimates of the impacts of the covered rules will be included in each analysis. Estimates of the impacts of covered rules and actions include effects on US economic competitiveness, costs and benefits, electricity and fuel prices, and employment over a 5-year period and in the long term. The curr_chunk discusses the impacts of covered rules and actions on various aspects such as energy prices, facility closures, bulk power supply reliability, consumers, small businesses, regional economies, governments, labor markets, and agriculture. The analysis includes key uncertainties, assumptions, sensitivity analysis, and cumulative impacts assessment. The Committee will use the best available methods and data, including air and water quality data, for analyzing covered rules. The term "covered rule" refers to specific published rules. The EPA published various National Ambient Air Quality Standards and Emission Standards for Hazardous Air Pollutants for different sources between 2010 and 2011. The EPA issued regulations for Fossil-Fuel-Fired Electric Utility, Industrial-Commercial-Institutional, and Small Industrial-Commercial-Institutional Steam Generating Units, Hazardous and Solid Waste Management, Disposal of Coal Combustion Residuals, Effluent Limitations Guidelines, and National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System requirements between 2009 and 2011. The EPA issued regulations for cooling water intake structures at existing facilities and amended requirements at phase I facilities in 2011. Additionally, rules or guidelines addressing climate change under the Clean Air Act were promulgated after January 1, 2009. The EPA issued regulations for cooling water intake structures at existing facilities in 2011 and rules or guidelines addressing climate change under the Clean Air Act after January 1, 2009. Covered actions include those by the EPA, states, local governments, or permitting agencies related to air quality standards. The curr_chunk discusses the application of Clean Air Act regulations, specifically related to greenhouse gases identified in a published document. This is in line with rules and guidelines addressing climate change under the Clean Air Act after January 1, 2009, as mentioned in the prev_chunk. The Committee is required to submit a preliminary report by January 31, 2012, and a final report by August 1, 2012, to Congress containing analyses conducted under section 3. A public comment period of 90 days will follow the submission of the preliminary report. An authorization of $2,000,000 for fiscal years 2012 and 2013 is allocated for the implementation of this Act.
